<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 216, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 115, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>?</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 353, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 368, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 397, 579, 414]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 414, 277, 429]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 429, 868, 460]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 459, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 475, 364, 491]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 491, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 670, 524]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 504, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a stone of irregular shape. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 98, 566, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 183, 920, 217]]<|/det|> Which property of the stone can be found by lowering it into a measuring cylinder half-filled with water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 227, 139, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 207, 245]]<|/det|> length <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 134, 271]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 253, 201, 271]]<|/det|> mass <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 138, 297]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 280, 217, 297]]<|/det|> volume <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 305, 138, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 305, 212, 323]]<|/det|> weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 350, 97, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 910, 367]]<|/det|> Two stones of different weights fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 380, 346, 397]]<|/det|> What will happen and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 408, 930, 539]]<|/det|>
what will happenwhy
ABoth stones hit the floor at the same time.Acceleration of free fall is constant.
BBoth stones hit the floor at the same time.They fall at constant speed.
CThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Acceleration increases with weight.
DThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Speed increases with weight.
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 565, 96, 584]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 599, 584]]<|/det|> The distance–time graph for a motorway journey is shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 593, 838, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 839, 475, 857]]<|/det|> What is the average speed for the journey? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 867, 134, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 867, 225, 885]]<|/det|> 50 km/h <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 867, 303, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 867, 393, 885]]<|/det|> 67 km/h <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 867, 495, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 867, 559, 885]]<|/det|> 70 km/h <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 867, 636, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 867, 727, 885]]<|/det|> 83 km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 855, 89]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows a sealed plastic bottle containing a hollow glass sphere and a steel ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 603, 120]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
Diagram 3 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken again until the broken glass is in tiny pieces.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 176, 922, 332]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 342, 571, 361]]<|/det|>
The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 1 is \(m_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 571, 390]]<|/det|>
The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 2 is \(m_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 571, 420]]<|/det|>
The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 3 is \(m_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 673, 451]]<|/det|>
Which statement gives the correct relation between \(m_{1}\), \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{3}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 134, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 460, 480, 479]]<|/det|>
\(m_{1}\) is equal to \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is equal to \(m_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 131, 505]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 488, 546, 505]]<|/det|>
\(m_{1}\) is greater than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 131, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 514, 522, 533]]<|/det|>
\(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 541, 131, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 541, 500, 560]]<|/det|>
\(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is less than \(m_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 584, 94, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 583, 534, 602]]<|/det|>

The box does not move because an object is in the way. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 480, 365]]<|/det|> Man Y lifts box Q from the floor onto a shelf. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 375, 902, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 808, 581]]<|/det|> Which man does the most work on their box, and which box gains the most energy? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 592, 453, 739]]<|/det|>
